--- title: "Lesson 8: Variability in estimates" author: "Meike Niederhausen and Nicky Wakim" title-slide-attributes: data-background-color: "#3070BF" date: "09/25/2024" categories: ["Week 6"] format: revealjs: theme: "../simple_NW.scss" toc: true toc-depth: 1 toc-title: Class Overview chalkboard: true slide-number: true show-slide-number: all width: 1600 height: 1100 footer: Lesson 8 Slides html-math-method: mathjax highlight-style: arrow execute: echo: true freeze: auto --- ## Where are we?

![](/img_slides/flowchart_511_v1.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Goals for today __Section 4.1__ * Sampling from a population * population parameters vs. point estimates * sampling variation * Sampling distribution of the mean * Central Limit Theorem ![[Artwork by @allison_horst](https://allisonhorst.com/)](/img_slides/horst_samples.png){fig-align="center"} ## MoRitz's tip of the day: add a code pane in RStudio Do you want to be able to view two code files side-by-side? You can do that by adding a column to the RStudio layout. ![](/img_slides/rstudio_pane_add_column_MM.jpg){fig-align="center"} See [https://posit.co/blog/rstudio-1-4-preview-multiple-source-columns/](https://posit.co/blog/rstudio-1-4-preview-multiple-source-columns/) for more information. ## Population vs. sample (from section 1.3) ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} __(Target) Population__ * group of interest being studied * group from which the sample is selected - studies often have _inclusion_ and/or _exclusion_ criteria __Sample__ * group on which data are collected * often a small subset of the population ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} __Simple random sample (SRS)__ * each individual of a population has the _same chance_ of being sampled * randomly sampled * considered best way to sample ![](/img_slides/sampleRandomHealthPlan.png){fig-align="center"} ::: ::: ## Population parameters vs. sample statistics ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} __Population parameter__ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} __Sample statistic (point estimate)__ ::: ::: ## Our hypothetical population: YRBSS __[Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System](https://www.cdc.gov/healthyyouth/data/yrbs/index.htm) (YRBSS)__ * Yearly survey conducted by the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC) * "A set of surveys that track behaviors that can lead to poor health in students grades 9 through 12."[^1] * Dataset `yrbss` from `oibiostat` pacakge contains responses from _n_ = 13,583 participants in 2013 for a subset of the variables included in the complete survey data [^1]: Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System [https://www.cdc.gov/healthyyouth/data/yrbs/index.htm](https://www.cdc.gov/healthyyouth/data/yrbs/index.htm) (YRBSS) ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(oibiostat) data("yrbss") #load the data # ?yrbss ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dim(yrbss) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 13583 13 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} names(yrbss) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "age" "gender" [3] "grade" "hispanic" [5] "race" "height" [7] "weight" "helmet.12m" [9] "text.while.driving.30d" "physically.active.7d" [11] "hours.tv.per.school.day" "strength.training.7d" [13] "school.night.hours.sleep" ``` ::: ::: ## Getting to know the dataset: `glimpse()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(yrbss) # from tidyverse package (dplyr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 13,583 Columns: 13 $ age 14, 14, 15, 15, 15, 15, 15, 14, 15, 15, 15, 1… $ gender "female", "female", "female", "female", "fema… $ grade "9", "9", "9", "9", "9", "9", "9", "9", "9", … $ hispanic "not", "not", "hispanic", "not", "not", "not"… $ race "Black or African American", "Black or Africa… $ height NA, NA, 1.73, 1.60, 1.50, 1.57, 1.65, 1.88, 1… $ weight NA, NA, 84.37, 55.79, 46.72, 67.13, 131.54, 7… $ helmet.12m "never", "never", "never", "never", "did not … $ text.while.driving.30d "0", NA, "30", "0", "did not drive", "did not… $ physically.active.7d 4, 2, 7, 0, 2, 1, 4, 4, 5, 0, 0, 0, 4, 7, 7, … $ hours.tv.per.school.day "5+", "5+", "5+", "2", "3", "5+", "5+", "5+",… $ strength.training.7d 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 2, 0, 3, 0, 3, 0, 0, 7, 7, … $ school.night.hours.sleep "8", "6", "<5", "6", "9", "8", "9", "6", "<5"… ``` ::: ::: ## Height & weight variables ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} yrbss %>% select(height, weight) %>% summary() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` height weight Min. :1.270 Min. : 29.94 1st Qu.:1.600 1st Qu.: 56.25 Median :1.680 Median : 64.41 Mean :1.691 Mean : 67.91 3rd Qu.:1.780 3rd Qu.: 76.20 Max. :2.110 Max. :180.99 NA's :1004 NA's :1004 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = yrbss, aes(x = height)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 1004 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_bin()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Transform height & weight from metric to to standard Also, drop missing values and add a column of id values ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} yrbss2 <- yrbss %>% # save new dataset with new name mutate( # add variables for height.ft = 3.28084*height, # height in feet weight.lb = 2.20462*weight # weight in pounds ) %>% drop_na(height.ft, weight.lb) %>% # drop rows w/ missing height/weight values mutate(id = 1:nrow(.)) %>% # add id column select(id, height.ft, weight.lb) # restrict dataset to columns of interest head(yrbss2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 5.675853 186.0038 2 2 5.249344 122.9957 3 3 4.921260 102.9998 4 4 5.150919 147.9961 5 5 5.413386 289.9957 6 6 6.167979 157.0130 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dim(yrbss2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 12579 3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # number of rows deleted that had missing values for height and/or weight: nrow(yrbss) - nrow(yrbss2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1004 ``` ::: ::: ## `yrbss2` summary ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(yrbss2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id height.ft weight.lb Min. : 1 Min. :4.167 Min. : 66.01 1st Qu.: 3146 1st Qu.:5.249 1st Qu.:124.01 Median : 6290 Median :5.512 Median :142.00 Mean : 6290 Mean :5.549 Mean :149.71 3rd Qu.: 9434 3rd Qu.:5.840 3rd Qu.:167.99 Max. :12579 Max. :6.923 Max. :399.01 ``` ::: ::: Another summary: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} yrbss2 %>% get_summary_stats(type = "mean_sd") %>% kable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} |variable | n| mean| sd| |:---------|-----:|--------:|--------:| |id | 12579| 6290.000| 3631.389| |height.ft | 12579| 5.549| 0.343| |weight.lb | 12579| 149.708| 37.254| ::: ::: ## Random sample of size n = 5 from `yrbss2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Take a random sample of size n = 5 from `yrbss2`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(moderndive) samp_n5_rep1 <- yrbss2 %>% rep_sample_n(size = 5, reps = 1, replace = FALSE) samp_n5_rep1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 4 # Groups: replicate [1] replicate id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 5869 5.15 145. 2 1 6694 5.41 127. 3 1 2517 5.74 130. 4 1 5372 6.07 180. 5 1 5403 6.07 163. ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Calculate the mean of the random sample: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means_hght_samp_n5_rep1 <- samp_n5_rep1 %>% summarise( mean_height = mean(height.ft)) means_hght_samp_n5_rep1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 replicate mean_height 1 1 5.69 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: [Would we get the same mean height if we took another sample?]{style="color:purple"} ## Sampling variation * If a different random sample is taken, the mean height (point estimate) will likely be different * this is a result of __[sampling variation]{style="color:darkorange"}__ ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Take a 2nd random sample of size n = 5 from `yrbss2`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} samp_n5_rep1 <- yrbss2 %>% rep_sample_n(size = 5, reps = 1, replace = FALSE) samp_n5_rep1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 × 4 # Groups: replicate [1] replicate id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 2329 6.07 182. 2 1 8863 5.25 125. 3 1 8058 5.84 135. 4 1 335 6.17 235. 5 1 4698 5.58 124. ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Calculate the mean of the 2nd random sample: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means_hght_samp_n5_rep1 <- samp_n5_rep1 %>% summarise( mean_height = mean(height.ft)) means_hght_samp_n5_rep1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 replicate mean_height 1 1 5.78 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: [Did we get the same mean height with our 2nd sample?]{style="color:purple"} ## 100 random samples of size n = 5 from `yrbss2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Take 100 random samples of size n = 5 from `yrbss2`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} samp_n5_rep100 <- yrbss2 %>% rep_sample_n(size = 5, reps = 100, replace = FALSE) samp_n5_rep100 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 500 × 4 # Groups: replicate [100] replicate id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 6483 5.51 145. 2 1 9899 4.92 90.0 3 1 6103 5.68 118. 4 1 2702 5.68 150. 5 1 11789 5.35 115. 6 2 10164 5.51 140. 7 2 5807 5.41 215. 8 2 9382 5.15 98.0 9 2 4904 6.00 196. 10 2 229 6.07 101. # ℹ 490 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Calculate the mean for each of the 100 random samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means_hght_samp_n5_rep100 <- samp_n5_rep100 %>% group_by(replicate) %>% summarise( mean_height = mean(height.ft)) means_hght_samp_n5_rep100 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 100 × 2 replicate mean_height 1 1 5.43 2 2 5.63 3 3 5.34 4 4 5.70 5 5 5.90 6 6 5.37 7 7 5.49 8 8 5.60 9 9 5.50 10 10 5.68 # ℹ 90 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: [How close are the mean heights for each of the 100 random samples?]{style="color:purple"} ## Distribution of 100 sample mean heights (n = 5) ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} Describe the distribution shape. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( means_hght_samp_n5_rep100, aes(x = mean_height)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="55%"} Calculate the mean and SD of the 100 mean heights from the 100 samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} stats_means_hght_samp_n5_rep100 <- means_hght_samp_n5_rep100 %>% summarise( mean_mean_height = mean(mean_height), sd_mean_height = sd(mean_height) ) stats_means_hght_samp_n5_rep100 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.58 0.150 ``` ::: ::: [Is the mean of the means close to the "center" of the distribution?]{style="color:purple"} ::: ::: ## 10,000 random samples of size n = 5 from `yrbss2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Take 10,000 random samples of size n = 5 from `yrbss2`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} samp_n5_rep10000 <- yrbss2 %>% rep_sample_n(size = 5, reps = 10000, replace = FALSE) samp_n5_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 50,000 × 4 # Groups: replicate [10,000] replicate id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 6383 5.35 126. 2 1 4019 5.41 107. 3 1 4856 5.25 135. 4 1 9988 5.58 120. 5 1 2245 6.17 270. 6 2 10580 5.68 155. 7 2 2254 5.84 159. 8 2 8081 5.09 110. 9 2 10194 5.35 115. 10 2 7689 5.35 135. # ℹ 49,990 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Calculate the mean for each of the 10,000 random samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000 <- samp_n5_rep10000 %>% group_by(replicate) %>% summarise( mean_height = mean(height.ft)) means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10,000 × 2 replicate mean_height 1 1 5.55 2 2 5.46 3 3 5.49 4 4 5.60 5 5 5.47 6 6 5.83 7 7 5.68 8 8 5.47 9 9 5.37 10 10 5.15 # ℹ 9,990 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: [How close are the mean heights for each of the 10,000 random samples?]{style="color:purple"} ## Distribution of 10,000 sample mean heights (n = 5) ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Describe the distribution shape. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000, aes(x = mean_height)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="52%"} Calculate the mean and SD of the 10,000 mean heights from the 10,000 samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} stats_means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000 <- means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000 %>% summarise( mean_mean_height=mean(mean_height), sd_mean_height = sd(mean_height) ) stats_means_hght_samp_n5_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.55 0.153 ``` ::: ::: [Is the mean of the means close to the "center" of the distribution?]{style="color:purple"} ::: ::: ## 10,000 samples of size n = 30 from `yrbss2` ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Take 10,000 random samples of size n = 30 from `yrbss2`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} samp_n30_rep10000 <- yrbss2 %>% rep_sample_n(size = 30, reps = 10000, replace = FALSE) samp_n30_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 300,000 × 4 # Groups: replicate [10,000] replicate id height.ft weight.lb 1 1 3871 5.25 115. 2 1 12090 5.15 125. 3 1 241 5.58 119. 4 1 4570 5.58 140. 5 1 4131 5.35 143. 6 1 11513 5.35 135. 7 1 9663 5.25 125. 8 1 3789 5.25 160. 9 1 442 5.15 130. 10 1 11528 5.51 200. # ℹ 299,990 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50"} Calculate the mean for each of the 10,000 random samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 <- samp_n30_rep10000 %>% group_by(replicate) %>% summarise(mean_height = mean(height.ft)) means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10,000 × 2 replicate mean_height 1 1 5.48 2 2 5.63 3 3 5.46 4 4 5.46 5 5 5.51 6 6 5.54 7 7 5.56 8 8 5.51 9 9 5.51 10 10 5.50 # ℹ 9,990 more rows ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: [How close are the mean heights for each of the 10,000 random samples?]{style="color:purple"} ## Distribution of 10,000 sample mean heights (n = 30) ::: columns ::: {.column width="48%"} Describe the distribution shape. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000, aes(x = mean_height)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="52%"} Calculate the mean and SD of the 10,000 mean heights from the 10,000 samples: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} stats_means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000<- means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 %>% summarise( mean_mean_height=mean(mean_height), sd_mean_height = sd(mean_height) ) stats_means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.55 0.0623 ``` ::: ::: [Is the mean of the means close to the "center" of the distribution?]{style="color:purple"} ::: ::: ## Compare distributions of 10,000 sample mean heights when n = 5 (left) vs. n = 30 (right) [How are the center, shape, and spread similar and/or different?]{style="color:purple"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.55 0.153 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.55 0.0623 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Sampling high schoolers' weights ::: columns ::: {.column width="100%"} Which figure is which? * Population distribution of weights * Sampling distribution of mean weights when $n=5$ * Sampling distribution of mean weights when $n=30$. ::: ::: ::: columns ::: {.column width="32%"} A ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="32%"} B ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="32%"} C ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## The sampling distribution of the mean ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} * The __[sampling distribution]{style="color:darkorang"}__ of the mean is the distribution of sample means calculated from repeated random samples of _the same size_ from the same population * Our simulations show approximations of the sampling distribution of the mean for various sample sizes * The theoretical sampling distribution is based on all possible samples of a given sample size $n$. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_bar()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_bar()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) * For **"large" sample sizes** ( $n\geq 30$ ), * the __sampling distribution__ of the sample mean * can be approximated by a __normal distribution__,with * _mean_ equal to the _population mean_ value $\mu$, and * _standard deviation_ $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$


* For **small sample sizes**, if the population is known to be normally distributed, then * the __sampling distribution__ of the sample mean * is a __normal distribution__, with * _mean_ equal to the _population mean_ value $\mu$, and * _standard deviation_ $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$ ## The cutest statistics video on YouTube * _[Bunnies, Dragons and the 'Normal' World: Central Limit Theorem]{style="color:purple"}_ * Creature Cast from the New York Times * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jvoxEYmQHNM&feature=youtu.be](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jvoxEYmQHNM&feature=youtu.be) ![](/img_slides/CLT_video_preview.png){fig-align="center" width=80%} ## Sampling distribution of mean heights when n = 30 (1/2) ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000, aes(x = mean_height)) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=480} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} CLT tells us that we can model the sampling distribution of mean heights using a normal distribution. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Sampling distribution of mean heights when n = 30 (2/2) ::: columns ::: {.column width="65%"} Mean and SD of population: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} (mean_height.ft <- mean(yrbss2$height.ft)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5.548691 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} (sd_height.ft <- sd(yrbss2$height.ft)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.3434949 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sd_height.ft/sqrt(30) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.06271331 ``` ::: ::: Mean and SD of simulated sampling distribution: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} stats_means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000<- means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 %>% summarise( mean_mean_height=mean(mean_height), sd_mean_height = sd(mean_height) ) stats_means_hght_samp_n30_rep10000 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 × 2 mean_mean_height sd_mean_height 1 5.55 0.0623 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](08_Variability_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=384} ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Why is the mean $\mu$ & the standard error $\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}$ ? ## Applying the CLT What is the probability that for a random sample of 30 high schoolers, that their mean height is greater than 5.6 ft? ## Class Discussion * Slide 21: match figures to distribution (Sampling high schoolers' weights) Problems from Homework 4: * R1: Youth weights (YRBSS) * Book exercise: 4.2 * Non-book exercise: Ethan Allen
